quoteFirst: what stage of her journey she had reached. The train had left Euston at half-past eight, and now the hour was
quoteLast: . Nearly two hours since she had gone away from him. Sixty or eighty miles, perhaps a hundred, separated them, and every moment the distance between them was lengthening.
title: The Foolish Lovers
author: Ervine, St. John G. (St. John Greer), 1883-1971

quoteFirst: In 1857, the Black River & Utica Railroad was operating a single passenger train a day, between Utica and Boonville. It left Boonville at eight o'clock in the morning and arrived at Utica at
quoteLast: The return run left Utica at 4:00 p. m. and arrived at Boonville at 6:20 p. m. Seventy-five cents was charged to ride from Utica to Trenton and $1.
title: The Story of the Rome, Watertown, and Ogdensburg Railroad
author: Hungerford, Edward, 1875-1948

quoteLast: --For half an hour firing lulled, but then recommenced, and is still going on. The _Ismailia_ was struck with a shell, but I hear is not seriously damaged. The _Husseinyeh_ is aground (I feel much the want of my other steamers at Metammeh). 11.15 a.m.--Firing has lulled; it was very heavy for the last three-quarters of an hour from _Ismailia_ and Arabs. It is now desultory, and is dying away.
title: The Egyptian campaigns, 1882 to 1885
author: Royle, Charles, 1882-1936

quoteFirst: As the creek below the camp trended to the west and entered a deep rocky gorge in the sandstone range, we steered south at 7.0 a.m., crossing several stony ridges with small gullies and creeks trending west; at
quoteLast: crossed the highest ridge, and observed a succession of low stony ridges occupying the space between us and the Sea Range. Descending, we reached a creek, on the bank of which we halted at 11.
title: Journals of Australian Explorations
author: Gregory, Augustus Charles, 1819-1905; Gregory, Francis Thomas, 1821-1888

quoteFirst: Bullocks arrived, and we started at
quoteLast: Camels and horses started at 12 o'clock. Came through some splendid feed to another lake containing but very little water and that quite bitter.

quoteFirst: He struck a match, and looked at the dial. It was a quarter past ten o'clock. Then, to occupy his mind, he began to try and count the three hundred seconds, fancying that he could see a pendulum swinging before his eyes in the dark. At
title: Paul Patoff

quoteFirst: In splendid weather, the rock being free from snow or ice, and, into the bargain, well known to one of the three of us, we did the climb without experiencing anywhere a moment’s delay. Time-table: Started from Cabane d’Orny, 5.50 a.m.; reached Col d’Orny, 7.15 a.m.; crossed Plateau du Trient to Col du Tour by 8.15 a.m.; passed foot of Aiguille Forbes by
quoteLast: ; set foot on _arête_ by 12 a.m.; reached top at 1.25 p.m.; completed descent of _arête_ by 3.20 p.m.; resumed our ski at 4.20 p.m.; skied back to Col du Tour by 5.40 p.m.; got home by 7 o’clock.
title: Ski-runs in the High Alps
author: Roget, F. F. (François Frédéric), 1859-
